[[Şakir Eczacıbaşı|Şakir]] (1929–2010) | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | signature_size = | website = | footnotes = }} '''Mehmet Nejat Ferit Eczacıbaşı''' ({{IPA-tr|mehˌmet neˌʒat feˌɾit edʒzaːˌdʒɯbaˈʃɯ}}, known simply as Nejat F. Eczacıbaşı, (January 5, 1913–October 6, 1993), a second generation member of the notable [[Turkey|Turkish]] [[Eczacıbaşı family]], was a [[chemist]], [[industrialist]], [[entrepreneur]] and [[philanthropist]]. He was the founder of [[Eczacıbaşı]], a prominent Turkish [[conglomerate (company)|industrial group]] with [[investment]]s in [[pharmaceuticals]], [[personal care]] products, [[consumer product]]s, [[building products]] and [[financial services]]. ==Early life and education== He was born on January 5, 1913 in [[Izmir]], [[Ottoman Empire]] to Süleyman Ferit Eczacıbaşı (1885–April 18, 1973) and his wife Saffet Hanım as their first of seven sons, Vedat (1916–1961),{{cite news |url=http://www.ensonhaber.com/eczacibasinin-mezari-acilacak-2011-02-15.html |newspaper=EnSonHaber |title=Eczacıbaşı'nın mezarı açıldı |date=2011-02-15 |language=Turkish |accessdate=2011-10-11 }} Sedat (1917–ca. 1950), Kemal (1918–1996),{{cite news |url=http://gazetearsivi.milliyet.com.tr/Arsiv/1996/03/05 |newspaper=[[Milliyet]] |title=İlan |date=1996-03-05 |language=Turkish |accessdate=2011-10-11 }} Haluk (1921–1996),{{cite web |url=http://www.24dakika.com/news_detail.php?id=38959 |publisher=4 Dakika |title=Tarihte bugün 6 Mayıs |date=2008-05-06 |language=Turkish |accessdate=2011-10-11 }} Melih (1923–2004),{{cite news |url=http://hurarsiv.hurriyet.com.tr/goster/ShowNew.aspx?id=260286 |newspaper=[[Hürriyet]] |title=Melih Eczacıbaşı toprağa verildi |date=3004-09-26 |language=Turkish |accessdate=2011-10-11 }} Şakir (1929–2010).{{cite news |url=http://hurarsiv.hurriyet.com.tr/goster/ShowNew.aspx?id=13640195 |newspaper=[[Hürriyet]] |title=Şakir Eczacıbaşı’nın ardından |date=2010-01-31 |language=Turkish |accessdate=2011-10-11 }} His father was the first university-educated [[pharmacist]] in the city of Izmir, who, while working at a hospital in his home town, was appointed "chief pharmacist" ({{lang-tr|baş eczacı}}. The city council awarded him later in 1909 the honorific title "Eczacıbaşı" for his fruitful and successful work. Süleyman Ferit ran in later years his own pharmacy in İzmir. With the introduction of the [[Surname Law]] in 1934, Süleyman Ferit adopted his title "Eczacıbaşı" as family name.{{cite web |url=http://www.kenthaber.com/ege/izmir/Kimdir/iz-birakan/suleyman-ferit-eczacibasi |publisher=Kent Haber İzmir |title=Süleyman Ferit Eczacıbaşı |language=Turkish |accessdate=2011-10-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110822133246/http://www.kenthaber.com/ege/izmir/Kimdir/iz-birakan/suleyman-ferit-eczacibasi |archivedate=2011-08-22 |df= }}{{cite web |url=http://pharmacy.ege.edu.tr/?p=diger&id=10;4 |publisher=Ege Üniversitesi |title=Süleyman Ferit Eczacıbaşı Şifa Eczanesi |language=Turkish |accessdate=2011-10-09 }} Nejat Eczacıbaşı completed his primary and secondary education in İzmir. After finishing the high school at [[Robert College]] in Istanbul, he went on to study in [[chemistry]] at [[Heidelberg University]]. He made then his [[master's degree]] at [[Chicago University]] and his [[doctorate]] in 1937 at [[Berlin University]].{{cite web |url=http://www.eczacibasi.com.tr/articles/detail/detail2.asp?id=344 |publisher=Eczacıbaşı Holding |title=Dr. Nejat F. Eczacıbaşı |language=Turkish |accessdate=2011-10-09 }} Nejat F. Eczacıbaşı conducted post-doctoral scientific works on [[hormone]]s and [[vitamin]]s at the [[Kaiser Wilhelm Institute]] in [[Germany]].{{cite web |url=http://www.turkcebilgi.com/ansiklopedi/nejat_eczac%C4%B1ba%C5%9F%C4%B1 |publisher=Türkçe Bilgi |title=Nejat Eczacıbaşı |language=Turkish |accessdate=2011-10-09 }} These studies contributed to Eczacıbaşı's scientific, systematic and universal approach to life and business, and reinforced his belief that the right to private enterprise ought to be tempered by social responsibility. This belief was first put forward by his father, whose maxim was "give back to your country what you take from it.{{cn|date=December 2016}} ==Career== After returning home, he settled in Istanbul, and started in 1942 with the production of vitamin drugs and [[baby food]] in a small laboratory. In 1952, he founded the country's first modern pharmaceutical plant. Like his father, he sought to uphold the aspirations of Turkey's founding fathers by contributing to the development of Turkish industry. Between 1950 and 1990, he oversaw the expansion of the Eczacıbaşı Group's activities from pharmaceuticals to building materials, tissue paper, personal health care, capital markets, foreign trade and information technology. He became a leading industrialist in branches such as pharmaceuticals, personal care products, consumer products, building products and financial services. In every one of these business ventures, gis cardinal principle was contribution to "a healthier society". Starting with his first business venture in the 1940s, Nejat F. Eczacıbaşı selected the most advanced technology available to manufacture products of international standards. ==Civic involvement and philanthropy== In addition to contributing to the development of Turkish industry, Nejat F. Eczacıbaşı sought to promote and assist the development of his country's civil society. His activities in this area included the establishment of educational institutions, professional business organisations, research institutes, cultural foundations and scholarship funds. In 1954, he helped to found the [[Istanbul University]]'s Institute of Business Administration, and the Turkish Management Association. In 1961, he established the Economic and Social Studies Conference Board, which would later become the Turkish Economic and Social Studies Foundation, one of the country's first independent strategic research institutes. Eczacıbaşı was the first president of the Turkish Educational Foundation, established in 1966 to provide scholarships for university and graduate students. He was also a member of the [[Middle East Technical University]]'s Board of Trustees during the 1960s and a member of the Board of Directors of the [[Scientific and Technological Research Council of Turkey|Turkish Scientific and Technical Research Institute]] in the 1970s. He was a principal founding member of the [[Turkish Industrialists' and Businessmen's Association]]. Nejat F. Eczacıbaşı used to say: "The meaning of life is best comprehended through the arts. The values which most exalt humankind are culture and the arts." Throughout his life, he saw to it that every new business venture was complemented by an additional contribution to culture, science, arts and education. Today, the Eczacıbaşı Group has become a unique symbol in Turkey of the bridge that can be forged between culture and private enterprise. Eczacıbaşı was one of the principal founders of the Istanbul Foundation for Culture and the Arts, which was established in 1973 on the 50th anniversary of the Turkish Republic. With the aim of transforming Istanbul into an "international capital of culture", the foundation initiated the annual International Istanbul Arts Festivals. Twenty years later, in recognition of the success of these festivals, [[UNESCO]] awarded the foundation the International Arts and Culture Trophy. The "Dr. Nejat F. Eczacıbaşı Foundation", established by him in 1978, provides scholarships for talented musicians, annual cinema and graphic arts awards and grants to public schools and institutes for scientific research. It also publishes books by distinguished authors and is developing a collection of modern Turkish paintings. The [[Eczacıbaşı#Sport|Eczacibasi Sports Club]], established jointly by Nejat F. Eczacıbaşı and his brother Şakir Eczacıbaşı in 1966, has trained innumerable young athletes and won a significant number of national and international championships in [[volleyball]], [[basketball]] and [[table tennis]]. In all that he did, Nejat F. Eczacıbaşı endeavoured to improve the standard of life for future generations and had the satisfaction of seeing his life's achievements contribute to these high aspirations. His memories of the early years of the [[Turkish Republic]] and of the growth of Turkish industry are recounted in his book "''Generation to Generation''" (1982). "''Experiences and Expectations''", published in 1994 soon after he died, recounts the lessons he drew from his unique experiences and the convictions that guided his life. Nejat Eczacıbaşı used to say that "the real measure of private entrepreneurship is the success with which it increases the wealth of the community as a whole". Dr. Eczacıbaşı also sustained that lasting success requires hard work, risks and innovation. "Success comes not to those who choose the easy path, but to those who dare to embrace innovations and advances." Nejat F. Eczacıbaşı lived by these convictions. ==Personal life and death== Nejat F. Eczacıbaşı married in 1946 to Fatma Beyhan (née Ergene) (1923–2004).{{cite news |url=http://webarsiv.hurriyet.com.tr/2004/08/29/513405.asp |newspaper=[[Hürriyet]] |title=Beyhan Eczacıbaşı toprağa verildi |date=2004-08-29 |language=Turkish |accessdate=2011-10-11 }} The couple has two sons, [[Bülent Eczacıbaşı|Bülent]] (1949) and Faruk (1954). Nejat F. Eczabaşıbaşı died on October 6, 1993 in [[Philadelphia]], [[Pennsylvania]], USA, he went there for [[cataract surgery]].{{cite news |url=http://gazetearsivi.milliyet.com.tr/Nejat%20Eczacibasi/ |newspaper=[[Milliyet]] |title=Sanayiden yıldız kaydı |date=1993-10-07 |language=Turkish |accessdate=2011-10-09}} His body was transferred to Istanbul, and was interred at the [[Zincirlikuyu Cemetery]].{{cite news |url=http://hurarsiv.hurriyet.com.tr/goster/printnews.aspx?DocID=253388 |newspaper=[[Hürriyet]] |title=Beyhan Eczacıbaşı’na son veda |date=2004-08-30 |language=Turkish |accessdate=2011-10-27 }} ==Awards and accolades== He was honored in 1974 by the [[Council of Europe]] for the successful [[Istanbul Festival]], he co-founded. In 1975 he was awarded with the "Medal of Honor" by the [[Turkish Red Crescent]], in 1976 with the [[Order of Merit of the Federal Republic of Germany|Order of Merit]] by the [[Federal Republic of Germany]]. In 1983, the Turkish Chemistry Association honored him for his contribution to the industry. ==See also== *[[Istanbul International Music Festival]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.eczacibasi.com.tr/ Eczacıbaşı Holding official website] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Eczacibasi, Nejat}} [[Category:Turkish businesspeople]] [[Category:1913 births]] [[Category:1993 deaths]] [[Category:Eczacıbaşı family|Nejat]] [[Category:People from Izmir]] [[Category:Heidelberg University alumni]] [[Category:University of Chicago alumni]] [[Category:Humboldt University of Berlin alumni]] [[Category:Turkish philanthropists]] [[Category:Turkish chemists]] [[Category:Turkish biochemists]] [[Category:Turkish chief executives]] [[Category:Burials at Zincirlikuyu Cemetery]]

{{use dmy dates|date=December 2012}} {{Infobox person |name = Nikolay Alekseyev |image = N.A.Alekseyev, 1852-1893, Mayor of Moscow since 1885, photo of 1880s.jpg |image_size = 150px |caption = |birth_name = |birth_date = 1852 |birth_place = Moscow |death_date = 25 ([[Old Style and New Style dates|OS]] 13) March 1893 |death_place = Moscow |body_discovered = |death_cause = Complications of a gunshot wound |resting_place = [[Novospassky Monastery]]
(grave destroyed) |resting_place_coordinates = |residence = |nationality = |ethnicity = |citizenship = [[Russian Empire]] |other_names = |known_for = |education = |alma_mater = |employer = |occupation = [[Mayor of Moscow]] |years_active = |home_town = |title = |salary = 12,000 roubles annually (refused to accept) |networth = |height = |weight = |term = |predecessor = |successor = |party = Non-partisan |opponents = |boards = |spouse = |partner = |children = |parents = |relations = |callsign = |signature = |website = |footnotes = }} '''Nikolay Aleksandrovich Alekseyev'''Spelled in contemporary English papers as ''Alexejeff'', ''Alexeieff'' ({{lang-ru|Николай Александрович Алексеев}}, 1852 –25 ([[Old Style and New Style dates|OS]] 13) March 1893) was the elected mayor of [[Moscow]] in 1885–1893. Alekseyev is credited with construction of the city's first [[sanitation]] system, the first pressurized [[water supply network]] reaching individual houses, a [[psychiatric hospital]] and 30 new public schools. Alekseyev reorganized the city finances, significantly increasing the share of [[non-tax revenue]] from city-owned commercial ventures, and was known for unorthodox and successful [[fundraising]] campaigns for the municipal charities. Alekseyev was a long-time sponsor of [[Moscow Conservatory]] and local musicians; during his tenure the city acquired the [[Tretyakov Gallery]]. Alekseyev was shot in his office by an insane visitor. He remains the only mayor of Moscow to be assassinated.[[Grand Duke Sergei Alexandrovich of Russia]], killed in 1905, was an appointed military governor, not an elected mayor. ==Biography== ===Family roots=== Nikolay Alekseyev belonged to the fourth generation of an old and wealthy family of traders and industrialists that settled in Alekseyevskaya Street (no direct connection)The street is named after the parish church of St.Alexis, established in the beginning of the 17th century. of [[Tagansky District]] after the [[Fire of Moscow (1812)|Fire of 1812]]. The area was a traditional [[Old Believers]] community, however, Alekseyevs were mainstream [[Russian Orthodox Church|Orthodox]]. Their main asset in Moscow, a [[copper]] [[foundry]] with wire-making plant, was placed one block to the north from the family mansion. The family was connected through marriages to Tretyakov, Mamontov, Chetverikov business clans, the [[Sheremetev]]sRuble 2001:292 and the Greek diaspora. A distant relative, Alexander Vasilyevich Alekseyev, has served as the mayor of Moscow in 1840–1841, although then the mayor's role was far less significant than in the 1880s.Orobey, Lobov 234 Alekseyev's mother was an ethnic [[Greeks|Greek]]; [[Boris Chicherin]], mayor of Moscow in 1882–1885, said that "Alekseyev's character merged cunning and refinement of a Greek with the arrogance of a Russian" ({{lang-ru|Он соединил в себе хитрость и утонченность грека с разнузданностью русской натуры}}). Actor and theater director [[Constantin Stanislavski|Konstantin Stanislavsky]], also born Alekseyev, was Nikolay's cousin; he chose a different stage name to disassociate the family from his theatrical endeavours. ===Early years=== Nikolay was [[home schooling|home schooled]], spoke three foreign languages, but never attended university or received any formal qualification. Like his cousin Konstantin, he leaned to the performing arts, spending his youth in the [[Bohemianism|bohemian]] musical circles. A close friend of [[Nikolai Grigoryevich Rubinstein|Nikolay Rubinstein]], Alekseyev co-financed [[Moscow Conservatory]] and independent Moscow Opera together with his older mentor [[Sergei Tretyakov (arts patron)|Sergei Tretyakov]] (mayor of Moscow in 1876–1882) and frequently acted as a manager for musicians. At the same time, Alekseyev in his twenties managed the [[textile]] assets of the family and was responsible for retooling the factories with modern machinery and technologies. His proactive, assertive attitudes were not always welcomed by Moscow elite; influential banker and [[philanthropist]], head of Moscow commodity exchange [[Nikolay Naidenov]] remained outspokenly hostile to Alekseyev throughout his life. This exposure to real-life business problems eventually led Alekseyev to seek public office. In 1880 he was elected to [[Moscow Governorate]] Duma, in 1881 to the Moscow City Duma; as the member of Duma he participated in various municipal activities from the school board to the coronation of [[Alexander III of Russia|Alexander III]] (1883).Ruble 2001:293 [[File:Moscow, Nikoloyamskaya 42.jpg|left|thumb|Alekseyev School of Music in [[Tagansky District]], originally an elementary municipal school. In 1884 Alekseyev donated the building to the city as a tribute to his late father.{{cite web | url=http://www.dmsh30.ru/history/ | title=History of the Alekseyev School of Music | language=Russian |accessdate=2008-10-01 }}]] ===1885 election=== The municipal election of 1885 was regulated by the City Statute of 1870. According to the law, all payers of [[property tax]] were eligible to vote; however, to dilute the share of small homeowners, the eligible voters were split into three unequal groups based on their tax assessment. In the 1880s these groups numbered 2–3, 5–6 and 12–15 thousand voters for a population of 753 thousand.1882 census figures; population grew at 2.5% p.a. — Orobey, Lobov 29 Each group elected 60 representatives to the City Duma. 180 members of the Duma elected the Mayor who, [[ex officio]], presided over the Duma sessions.Orobey, Lobov 238 [[Boris Chicherin]] described the members of the Duma as "absent nobles, indifferent merchants and arrogant democracy".Orobey, Lobov 239 The latter group consisted of uneducated petty traders, laborers and farmers, and was known as the [[Black Hundreds|black hundred]].The term ''black hundred'' re-emerged as the umbrella for ultra-right movements later, around 1900 Savvy beyond reasonable limit, the ''black hundred'' regularly blocked legitimate municipal projects as too expensive or unnecessary.The situation was "improved" in 1892 with the law which imposed a tax minimum for eligibility. The number of candidates at the Duma election was unlimited; [[election by list]] voting with [[Blackballing|black and white balls]] was time-consuming, causing voter absenteeism. Contemporaries estimated that only 3 to 6% of less than 20 thousand eligible voters showed up at the 1880 elections.Orobey, Lobov 239 Politics were dominated by around 300 wealthy families, many of them parts of historical business clans.Brumfield et al. 2001:66 In 1885, Alekseyev, then only 32 years old, succeeded in bringing the sleeper voters to the elections, thus reducing the weight of ''black hundred'' and easily winning the mayoral ballot in November. He succeeded in shaping up a loyal majority coalition; balancing between a strongman administration and continuous mediation of the rivalling clans, Alekseyev managed to maintain support for his initiatives in the Duma and among the business circles.Ruble 2001:294 [[File:Moscow, Water Towers, Max Hoeppener, 1890s.jpg|thumb|right|Two water towers, erected in 1892, provided pressure for the new water supply. They were demolished in the 1930s to make way for the expansion of [[Mira Avenue|Prospekt Mira]].]] ===Municipal projects=== Alekseyev started his tenure with the controversial shutdown of the Upper Trade Rows on the [[Red Square]]. The building, erected in 1815 by [[Joseph Bove]], was torn down in 1889 and replaced with the [[Main Department Store|new Upper Trade Rows]], designed by [[Alexander Pomerantsev]], in 1890–1893. In 1890 he launched construction of a [[Moscow City Hall|new Duma building]] on the nearby Voskresenskaya Square; the project was criticized for its outward [[Russian Revival|pseudo-Russian]] style and cost overruns.Orobey, Lobov 252 Moscow of 1885 had no [[sanitation]] and no [[water supply network]] in present sense: water flowed from [[Mytishchi]] in the open trench of the [[Rostokino Aqueduct]] and was distributed to a limited number of [[fountain]]s on the central squares. In the 1870s the city built three local water networks of inadequate capacity that were abandoned by 1885. After long disputes between supporters of municipal and private water supply, in 1888 the city settled on building a single pressurized water system.Orobey, Lobov 267 Key element of the system – two tower-like water reservoirs near present-day [[Rizhsky Rail Terminal]] – were partially financed with Alekseyev's personal funds. The main distribution pipeline, 108 [[verst]]s long, was completed during Alekseyev's tenure in 1892. In 1896 the system reached individual houses along the Garden Ring and in 1912 the city was able to require mandatory hookup to running water for all new buildings within the city limits.Orobey, Lobov 268 In 1886–1889 Alekseyev sponsored detailed feasibility study of various [[sewage]] system layout. The modular plan, adopted in 1889, divided the city into practically independent parts (central and peripheral), making a provision for subsequent expansion of the city. The project was delayed by budget constraints; in 1892 the city raised money through a 49-year loan. The first 37 [[verst]]s of large-bore sewage pipes were operational in 1894, half a year since Alekseyev's death; by the end of 1895 half of the system was complete and the city laid out its first [[sewage treatment]] facility. Alekseyev supervised construction of a large municipal [[slaughterhouse]] placed beyond the city limits (present-day Mikoyan meat-processing plant); with its completion all inner city slaughterhouses were shut down. Alekseyev, personally attached to the fate of the [[Mental disorder|mentally sick]], called for construction of a new [[psychiatric hospital]] in 1889; existing psychiatric hospital in [[Preobrazhenskaya hospital|Preobrazhenskoe]], built before the [[Napoleon's invasion of Russia|war of 1812]], was inadequate for the growing city. Alekseyev personally rallied wealthy muscovites for donations, his fundraising antics became a source of anecdotes.Ruble 2001:294, 306–307 provides bibliography of English versions of these fundraising-related anecdotes. Amounts of money and personalities of Alekseyev's opponents vary; all these stories revolve around successful fundraising bordering with [[extortion]]. Nevertheless, he raised enough money to finance the first stage of the hospital which opened in 1894. Contemporary studies of Moscow charities assert that Alekseyev's efforts radically changed the pattern of business donations to the charities; they became a standard of business practice and continued to grow for two decades after his death.Brumfield et al. 2001:96 In seven and half years of Alekseyev's tenure Moscow acquired 30 new schools, its first [[asphalt]] pavement, first permanent electrical power plant (1888),The first powerplant, built for the coronation of Alexander III in 1883, was not intended for continuous operation. unified tram system (1891)In 1891 two existing horse tram networks were united under a common management — Orobey, Lobov 278 and the [[Tretyakov Gallery]] (1892). ===Municipal finance=== Alekseyev's projects unbalanced the city budget, which operated at a significant deficit throughout the 1880s. He responded with investments into revenue-generating municipal enterprises. 1888, the year when the new central slaughterhouse became operational, is considered a breakthrough year: the city acquired its first large profitable asset. Income from city enterprises grew slowly but surely and by 1913 accounted for 55% of the city revenue.Orobey, Lobov 254, 257 Constrained with political connections, Alekseyev was reluctant to increase taxes; property taxes grew proportionate to city expansion, while the business tax rates decreased (collection remained at the same nominal amount despite rapid growth of the economy). {| class="wikitable" border="1" |- ! He was reluctant to borrow more due to the Duma opposition against loans; the first major loan of this tenure was approved in 1892 to finance sewage system. ===Relations with the Jews=== [[Grand Duke Sergei Alexandrovich of Russia]], appointed Governor of Moscow in February 1891, initiated a royal order for deportation of [[Jews]] from the city into the [[Pale of Settlement]]. The decree directly affected nearly half of estimated 20 thousands Moscow Jews, even including retired soldiers. According to the Western sources, Alekseyev supported the deportation and provided the city resources to the police action managed by the Grand Duke. The operation continued at the time of Alekseyev's death and installed "an eternal hatred for him among the Russian-Jewish diaspora." S. M. Dubnow, author of "History of Jews in Poland and Russia" (1918) even branded Alekseyev "an ignorant merchant with a shady reputation", and alleged that his efforts were motivated by rivalry with Jewish banker [[Lazar Polyakov]] (incorrectly described as the owner of a "rural bank").Dubnow ch.XXIX.2 On the contrary, Alekseyev sided with prime minister [[Sergei Witte|Witte]] in his campaign in support of [[Bukharan Jews]]. This may be explained by long-standing ties between Moscow textile industry and the Central Asian [[cotton]] traders (including Bukharan Jews).Ruble, 2001:295 ===Death and legacy=== March 21 ([[Old Style and New Style dates|OS]] 9), 1893, a man named Andrianov fatally shot the mayor in his City Hall study. Early reports called the shooter a [[Nihilist movement|nihilist]],This version was reproduced in British and American newspapers on March 22–23, 1893 (e.g. [[Hartford Courant]], March 22) but he was later attested to be insane. After four days of agony, Alekseyev died on March 25 (OS 13). Shortly before his death he instructed his wife to pledge 300,000 roubles of their personal wealth to the completion of the psychiatric hospital; the wish was fulfilled, and the hospital, inaugurated in 1894, was named in Alekseyev's honour.In 1922 the hospital was renamed after psychiatrist [[Pyotr Kashchenko]]. The original name, ''N. A. Alekseyev First Psychiatric Hospital'', was restored in 1994. His funeral at [[Novospassky Monastery]] cemetery was attended by 200 thousand mourners.Orobey, Lobov 245 The cemetery was destroyed in the 1930s, and the site of his grave was lost. Alekseyev's achievements and charismatic personality became a yardstick for evaluation of municipal officers until [[World War I]]. His immediate successor, Konstantin Rukavishnikov, completed the projects launched by Alekseyev and got rid of the [[budget deficit]], but lost the 1897 reelection to the public opinion of "not matching his too splendid forerunner". The city remained divided into pro-Alekseyev and anti-Alekseyev factions; his memories were frequently invoked by politicians for support of their own and for denigration of their opponents' initiatives. ==See also== * [[Carter Harrison Sr.]], [[Carter Harrison Jr.]] and [[Seki Hajime]] — contemporary mayors of [[Chicago]] and [[Osaka]] analyzed in the Blair A. Ruble book (see References) * [[:commons:Category:Max Hoeppener|Max Hoeppener]] — lead architect of municipal projects in Moscow during Alekseyev's tenure ==References== * {{cite book | authors=Orobey, O. N. (compilation), Lobov O. I. (editor) | title=Stroiteli Rossii, XX vek. Moskva nachala veka (''Строители России, ХХ век. Москва начала века'') | publisher=O-Master, Moscow | year=2001 | isbn=5-9207-0001-7 |language=Russian}} * {{cite book | author=Ruble, Blair A. | title=Second Metropolis: Pragmatic Pluralism in Gilded Age Chicago, Silver Age Moscow, and Meiji Osaka | publisher=Woodrow Wilson Center Press | year=2004 | isbn=978-1-930365-15-5 }} * An abridged version of above text by Ruble is also included as an article in: :* {{cite book | editors=Brumfield, Anan'ich, Petrov | title=Commerce in Russian Urban Culture, 1861–1914 | publisher=Woodrow Wilson Center Press, Johns Hopkins University Press | year=2002 | isbn=978-0-8018-6750-7 }} and :* {{cite book | editors=Brumfield, Anan'ich, Petrov | title=Predprinimatelstvo i gorodskaya kultura v Rossii 1861–1914 (''Предпринимательство и городская культура в России'') | language=Russian | publisher=Tri Kvadrata, Moscow | year=2001 |isbn=94-6070-110-8 }} * {{cite web | author=Dubnow, S. M. | title=History of Jews in Poland and Russia, vol.2 | url=https://archive.org/stream/historyofthejews15729gut/15729-8.txt | publisher=The Jewish publication society of America, Philadelphia | year=1918 }} ==Notes== {{Reflist|2}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Alekseyev, Nikolay}} [[Category:Mayors of Moscow]] [[Category:Russian businesspeople]] [[Category:Assassinated mayors]] [[Category:Assassinated Russian politicians]] [[Category:1852 births]] [[Category:1893 deaths]] [[Category:People murdered in Russia]] [[Category:Russian murder victims]] [[Category:Deaths by firearm in Russia]] [[Category:Russian people of Greek descent]]

{{multiple issues| {{Underlinked|date=January 2013}} {{Orphan|date=January 2011}} {{advert|date=May 2013}} }} {{Infobox company |name=PivotLink |industry=Software |type=Private |foundation= 1998 |location=San Francisco, California |num_employees=50+ |homepage= {{URL|http://www.pivotlink.com/}} }} '''PivotLink''' is based in [[San Francisco|San Francisco, California]] with development and services operations in [[Bellevue, Washington]]. ==Backing== Originally a privately held company backed by Trident Capital, Emergence Capital Partners, StarVest Partners and Pelion Venture Partners. PivotLink raised $13 million in its latest funding round in January 2012.{{cite web|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/sanfrancisco/news/2012/01/18/pivotlink-raises-13-million.html|title=SF Business Times Article |publisher=SF Business Times |date=2012-01-18 |accessdate=2012-01-18}} In May 2014, the company was acquired by [[Francisco Partners]] backed SaaS marketing platform, [[SmartFocus]].{{cite web|url=http://www.websitemagazine.com/content/blogs/posts/archive/2014/05/16/cloud-marketing-platform-acquires-amp-hires.aspx|title=Cloud Marketing Platform Acquires & Hires |publisher=Website Magazine |date=16 May 2014}} ==History== PivotLink was founded by Samuel Koshy and Ching Wan in 1998 on the idea that it should be easy for business users to securely analyze data however they want and share their insights with colleagues and partners wherever they are.{{cite web|url=http://www.dashboardinsight.com/articles/one-on-one-with-dashboard-insight/one-on-one-with-dyke-hensen.aspx |title=One-on-One with Dyke Hensen |publisher=Dashboardinsight.com |date=2009-09-30 |accessdate=2012-05-07}} ==Executives== The PivotLink management team is made up of personnel from the SaaS Marketing Analytics, Business Intelligence and [[Data warehousing|Data Warehousing]] industries. Bruce Armstrong – President & Chief Executive Officer
Samuel Koshy - Founder, Chief Operating Officer
Ching Wan – Founder, Chief Data Scientist
Tom Muise – Chief Financial Officer
Joe Dalton – Chief Product Officer
Jeff Schmidt – Chief Revenue Officer ==Products== The PivotLink Business Intelligence Platform is designed for business users to quickly explore data to make decisions with limited IT involvement. The PivotLink [[solution]] uses a highly simplified data structure and in-memory analytics engine to power dynamic reports and collaborative dashboards in a highly secure manner.{{cite web|url=http://www.crunchbase.com/company/pivotlink-formerly-seatab |title=PivotLink – CrunchBase Profile |publisher=Crunchbase.com |date= |accessdate=2012-05-07}} PivotLink also offers a line of ReadiMetrix quick-start [[solution]]s that offer a mix of pre-built reports, key performance indicators (KPIs) and collaborative dashboards for a variety of functions and industries, including sales, retail, marketing, online marketing, and human resources. The ReadiMetrix products were built on industry best practices and feedback from some of PivotLink’s 15,000 users.{{cite web|last=Whiting |first=Rick |url=http://www.crn.com/news/applications-os/224000365/pivotlink-adds-analytical-apps-to-saas-bi-platform.htm;jsessionid=ALJWn63y2z2tLEXuxSQQpQ**.ecappj02 |title=PivotLink Adds Analytical Apps To SaaS BI Platform |publisher=Crn.com |date=2010-03-22 |accessdate=2012-05-07}} ==Customers== PivotLink serves retail and retail-related customers such as: Car Toys; Freshpair; Kelly-Moore; Party City; Rossignol; Shaklee; and Timbuk2. ==News== PivotLink Expands Its ReadiMetrix Portfolio, Financial Tech Spotlight[http://www.financial.tmcnet.com/topics/financial-technology/articles/108996-pivotlink-expands-its-readimetrix-portfolio.htm] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101020140420/http://www.financial.tmcnet.com/topics/financial-technology/articles/108996-pivotlink-expands-its-readimetrix-portfolio.htm|date=October 20, 2010}} Cloud Marketing Platform Acquires & Hires{{cite web|url=http://www.websitemagazine.com/content/blogs/posts/archive/2014/05/16/cloud-marketing-platform-acquires-amp-hires.aspx|title=Cloud Marketing Platform Acquires & Hires |publisher=Website Magazine |date=16 May 2014}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Pivotlink}} [[Category:Business intelligence companies]]

{{Infobox Union |name= Planka.nu |country= [[Sweden]] |affiliation= |members= |full_name= |native_name= Planka.nu |image= [[Image:Hoppagubben.gif|150px]] |founded= 2001 |current= |head= |dissolved_date= |dissolved_state= |merged_into= |office= |people= |website= [http://planka.nu planka.nu] |footnotes= }}
'''Planka.nu''' is a network of organizations in [[Sweden]] and [[Norway]] promoting [[tax]]-financed [[zero-fare public transport]] with chapters in [[Stockholm]], [[Gothenburg]], [[Skåne]], [[Östergötland]] and [[Oslo]].<ref name="planka-om">{{cite web | url = http://planka.nu/om-plankanu | title = Om Planka.nu | work = Planka.nu | accessdate = 2010-01-25 | quote = }}</ref> Planka.nu was founded in 2001 by the [[Swedish Anarcho-syndicalist Youth Federation]] in response to the increasingly expensive ticket prices in the [[Public transport in Stockholm|public transport system in Stockholm]]. The campaign has received much attention because of the controversial methods used to promote free [[public transport]]: Planka.nu encourage people to [[Fare dodging|fare-dodge]] in the public transport,<ref name="fpt">{{cite web | url = http://www.freepublictransports.com/Planka.nu | title = Planka.nu | work = Free Public Transport | accessdate = 2010-01-25 | quote = }}</ref> <ref name="planka-darfor">{{cite web | url = http://planka.nu/vad-tycker-vi/darfor-vagrar-vi-betala | title = Avgiftsstrejk | work = Planka.nu | accessdate = 2010-01-25 | quote = }}</ref> aiding its members in paying [[penalty fare]]s through the insurance fund ''p-kassan''.<ref name="planka-pkassan">{{cite web | url = http://planka.nu/plankning/stockholm/pkassan | title = P-kassan är en bötesfond för plankare i Stockholms kollektivtrafik | work = Planka.nu | accessdate = 2010-01-24 | quote = P-kassan är en solidaritetskassa. Som medlem hjälper du andra plankare att få sina böter betalda. När du själv åker fast är det andra plankare som betalar din tilläggsavgift. }}</ref>
== History == In 2001, the Stockholm chapter of the Swedish Anarcho-syndicalist Youth Federation ({{lang-sv|SUF, Syndikalistiska Ungdomsförbundet}}) launched the campaign Planka.nu (literally, ''fare-dodge.now'') as a reaction to a rise in ticket prices by the [[Stockholm County Council]].<ref name="planka-om"/> The domain name [[.nu]], which belongs to the {{convert|260|km²|adj=on}} island of [[Niue]] but is sold primarily to foreigners, was chosen because it means "now" in [[Swedish language|Swedish]]. The standard [[top level domain]] for Sweden is [[.se]].
With growing membership and interest, the campaign was detached from the SUF to form an independent organization. Local organizations have since started up in [[Gothenburg]] in 2003, [[Östergötland]] in 2005 and [[Skåne]] in 2009.<ref name=planka-om /> A sister organization, ''pumm.it'' has been created in [[Helsinki]], [[Finland]].<ref name="pummit">{{cite web |url = http://planka.nu/pummit |title = Pummit - moi mukulat |work = Planka.nu |accessdate = 2010-01-26 |quote = |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100813125840/http://planka.nu/pummit |archivedate = 2010-08-13 |df = }}</ref> In November 2008, Planka.nu released [http://freepublictransports.com Freepublictransports.com], a global forum for the free public transport movement.
Ticket fares in Stockholm have increased dramatically over time. By one measure—single ticket price for a {{convert|10|km|adj=on}} journey—Stockholm has the most expensive-to-use public transport in the world, as of March 2009.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.economist.com/displayStory.cfm?story_id=14396066 |title=A fare price?| publisher=[[The Economist]]| date=September 24, 2009| accessdate=2009-09-24| quote=In Stockholm it costs $4.88 for a single journey of 10km on public transport, the highest cost in a study of 73 cities by [[UBS AG|UBS]], a Swiss bank.}}</ref>
== Activism == [[File:COP15Plankanu.jpg|thumb|250px|Planka.nu demonstrating at the [[COP15]].]] In the tradition of the [[Italians|Italian]] [[autonomist]]s,<ref name="indymedia">{{cite web| url =http://sweden.indymedia.org/newswire/display_any/20075| title =Planka.nu och autoreduktion| first =| last =SAM| date =2002-04-20| month =| year =| work =IMC Sverige| publisher =[[Indymedia]]| accessdate =2010-01-25| quote =| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://archive.is/20130415012936/http://sweden.indymedia.org/newswire/display_any/20075| archivedate =2013-04-15| df =}}</ref> Planka.nu advocate [[self-reduction]], where the price of the [[Service (economics)|service]] is determined by the [[consumer]].<ref name="planka-sjalvreduktion">{{cite web | url = http://planka.nu/vad-tycker-vi/sjalvreduktion | title = Självreduktion | work = Planka.nu | accessdate = 2010-01-25 | quote = }}</ref> Whereas in other cases this is done in agreement with (at least some) [[employee]]s of the [[service provider]], in the case of Planka.nu fare-dodgers are encouraged to evade fares without seeking permission.
Since its conception Planka.nu has broadened its methods and now functions as a [[think tank]] with public transport, [[urban planning]] and [[Global warming|climate change]] as its main areas of focus,<ref name=fpt /><ref name="fpt-annual09">{{cite web | url = http://www.freepublictransports.com/blog/2010/01/annual-report-from-planka-nu-stockholm-sweden/ | title = Annual report from Planka.nu (Stockholm, Sweden) | work = Free Public Transport | accessdate = 2010-02-01 | quote = }}</ref> as well as an insurance fund. The network also uses standard [[leftist]] methods, such as [[Demonstration (people)|rallies]],<ref name="fpt-annual08">{{cite web | url = http://www.freepublictransports.com/blog/2009/05/annual-report-for-2008-from-plankanu-stockholm-sweden/ | title = Annual report for 2008 from Planka.nu (Stockholm, Sweden) | work = Free Public Transport | accessdate = 2010-02-01 | quote = }}</ref> [[adbusting]],<ref name=fpt-annual09 /> and [[pamphlet]]s.<ref name="planka-information">{{cite web |url = http://planka.nu/engagera-dig/informationsmaterial |title = Informationsmaterial |work = Planka.nu |accessdate = 2010-02-01 |quote = |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100302014519/http://www.planka.nu/engagera-dig/informationsmaterial |archivedate = 2010-03-02 |df = }}</ref> Together with refugee rights organization [http://ingenillegal.org/introduction Ingen människa är illegal], the Swedish chapter of [[No one is illegal]], Planka.nu provides tickets for [[immigrant]]s living in Sweden without [[right to asylum|asylum]],<ref name=planka-ekonomi /> since a [[Illegal immigration|paperless immigrant]] might otherwise be reported to the police and deported if caught riding without a ticket.
=== P-kassan === Failing to purchase a ticket or traveling using an incorrect pass is subject to a [[penalty fare]] of 1200 [[Swedish krona|SEK]] in the public transport systems of Stockholm,<ref>{{cite web|title=Om du fuskåker|publisher=AB Storstockholms Lokaltrafik|url=http://sl.se/Resenar/Resegaranti-resevillkor/Resa-utan-eller-med-fel-biljett/|accessdate=2010-10-17|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100824205024/https://sl.se/Resenar/Resegaranti-resevillkor/Resa-utan-eller-med-fel-biljett/|archivedate=2010-08-24|df=}}</ref> Gothenburg<ref>{{cite web|title=Biljettkontroll|publisher=Västtrafik|url=http://www.vasttrafik.se/sv/Att-resa/Biljettkontroll/|accessdate=2010-01-26}}</ref> and Östergötland.<ref>{{cite web|title=Du har väl giltig biljett?|publisher=ÖstgötaTrafiken|url=http://www.ostgotatrafiken.se/templates/WidePage____9645.aspx|accessdate=2010-01-26|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080121202301/http://www.ostgotatrafiken.se/templates/WidePage____9645.aspx|archivedate=2008-01-21|df=}}</ref> In return for a membership fee (paid monthly or biannually) members are refunded by Planka.nu if fined, through the solidarity fund ''P-kassan''.<ref name=planka-pkassan /> Net income from p-kassan is used in the aforementioned partnership with ''No one is illegal'' and to finance the production of flyers, stickers, folders, web pages and other information material. All members of Planka.nu work [[pro-bono]].<ref name="planka-ekonomi">{{cite web | url = http://planka.nu/om-plankanu/ekonomi | title = Ekonomi | work = Planka.nu | accessdate = 2010-10-17 | quote = }}</ref><ref name="tv4-cliffordson">{{Citation |last = Cliffordson |first = Ida |date = 2010-01-20 |title = Planka.nu anmäls till skatteverket |edition = |series = TV4Nyheterna Göteborg |place = |publication-place = |publisher = [[TV4 (Sweden)|TV4]] |url = http://www.tv4play.se/nyheter/lokala_nyheter/goteborg?videoId=1.1452297 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120302091524/http://www.tv4play.se/nyheter/lokala_nyheter/goteborg?videoId=1.1452297 |archivedate = 2012-03-02 |df = }}</ref>
In December 2009, [[Västtrafik]] accused the Gothenburg chapter of operating an unauthorized insurance.<ref name=tv4-cliffordson /><ref name="gp-nystrom">{{cite web | url = http://www.gp.se/nyheter/goteborg/1.264921-vasttrafik-vill-stoppa-planka-nu | title = Västtrafik vill stoppa planka.nu | first = Ulf | last = Nyström | date = 2009-12-04 | month = | year = | work = GP.se | publisher = | accessdate = 2010-01-24 | quote = Organisationen planka.nu bedriver försäkringsverksamhet, säger Johnny Bröndt (M), vice ordförande i Västtrafiks styrelse. […] Så vet jag vet har planka.nu varken tillstånd till försäkringsverksamhet eller deklarerar intäkter, utgifter och eventuellt överskott. Det är inte längre någon ideell organisation.}}</ref>
== Criticism == {{see also|Free public transport#Criticism}} Planka.nu and its organizers have seen substantial criticism, primarily by politicians and transportation companies in each city. The network has been reported to the police for [[incitement]] by [[Storstockholms Lokaltrafik]] (SL),<ref name="dn-hermele">{{cite web | url = http://www.dn.se/sthlm/sl-polisanmaler-plankanu-1.299698 | title = SL polisanmäler Planka.nu | first = Bernt | last = Hermele | date = 2004-08-21 | month = | year = | work = DN.se | publisher = | accessdate = 2010-01-25 | quote = }}</ref> Västtrafik and ÖstgötaTrafiken, who believe that Planka.nu engages in illegal activities. As of today, no charges have been made. Planka.nu themselves believe that their activities do not conflict with existing legislation.<ref name="planka-lagligt">{{cite web | url = http://planka.nu/kto/lagligt | title = Lagligt? | work = Planka.nu | accessdate = 2010-01-26 | quote = }}</ref>
Many critics believe that [[fare evasion]] leads to reduced funds and higher costs for public transport, which must be offset by higher prices for those who do pay their fares.<ref name=gp-nystrom /><ref name="dn-palmgren">{{citation | last = Palmgren | first = Nils | title = Skärpt strid om fuskåkning | date = 2004-05-27 | month = | year = | work = [[Dagens Nyheter]] | publisher = | quote = 200 miljoner kronor om året kostar fuskåkandet SL varje år. Enligt företaget gör det månadskortet 50 kronor dyrare än vad det skulle behöva vara.}}</ref>
In 2004, the [[Stockholm University#Student unions|Stockholm University Student Union]] received media attention after first permitting a meeting of the network on its premises and later barring Planka.nu when criticism was voiced.<ref name="dn-kihlstrom">{{cite web | url = http://www.dn.se/sthlm/plankanu-vallar-spricka-i-studentkar-1.319281 | title = Planka.nu vållar spricka i studentkår | first = Staffan | last = Kihlström | date = 2004-10-23 | month = | year = | work = DN.se | publisher = | accessdate = 2010-01-25 | quote = }}</ref>
== Publications == Planka.nu has released four larger [[White paper|policy papers]]: ''Highway to Hell?'' criticizing the plans for the express [[beltway]] [[Förbifart Stockholm]] around [[Stockholm]],<ref name="highwaypdf">{{Citation |title = Highway to Hell? |url = http://planka.nu/reports/plankanu_highway_to_hell.pdf |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100813125420/http://planka.nu/reports/plankanu_highway_to_hell.pdf |archivedate = 2010-08-13 |format = |accessdate = 2010-01-25 |date = November 2007 |publisher = Planka.nu |language = Swedish |deadurl = yes |df = }}</ref> ''Travel Doesn't Have to Cost the Earth'' proposing a set of measures to make the transport sector in Stockholm more [[Economics of global warming#Mitigation|climate-friendly]],<ref name="travelpdf">{{Citation |title = Travel Doesn't Have to Cost the Earth |url = http://planka.nu/reports/planka_stockholm_report.pdf |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20091229175958/http://planka.nu/reports/planka_stockholm_report.pdf |archivedate = 2009-12-29 |format = |accessdate = 2010-01-25 |date = 2009-09-22 |origyear = 2008 |publisher = Planka.nu |deadurl = yes |df = }}</ref> ''Till varje pris?'' (''At any cost?'') a report about the costs of ticketing in the public transport system in Stockholm,<ref name="tillvarjepdf">{{Citation |title = Till varje pris? |url = http://planka.nu/reports/plankanu_till_varje_pris.pdf |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100812215850/http://planka.nu/reports/plankanu_till_varje_pris.pdf |archivedate = 2010-08-12 |format = |accessdate = 2010-01-25 |date = March 2009 |publisher = Planka.nu |language = Swedish |deadurl = yes |df = }}</ref> and ''Trafikmaktsordningen'' (''The Trafic Power Structure'') regarding the [[hierarchy|hierarchies]] of [[transportation]] and how it relates to [[social mobility]] and [[social class|class]].<ref name="trafikmaktpdf">{{Citation |title = Trafikmaktsordningen |url = http://planka.nu/reports/plankanu_trafikmaktsordningen.pdf |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20091222033223/http://planka.nu/reports/plankanu_trafikmaktsordningen.pdf |archivedate = 2009-12-22 |format = |accessdate = 2010-01-25 |date = December 2009 |publisher = Planka.nu |language = Swedish |deadurl = yes |df = }}</ref>

{{infobox recurring event |name = Samriddhi |logo = |genre = Student-run business conference/fest |filing = |founded = 2006 |location = Sanquelim, Goa, India |coordinates = |sponsor = [[Goa Institute of Management]] |events = Business Conference, Quizzes, Case Studies Etc. |participants_title = Guests |participants = Alyque Padamsee, Mithileshwar Jha, Kumar Ankit, Stephen Remedios, |website = [http://www.gim-samriddhi.com www.gim-samriddhi.com] |footnotes = }} '''Samriddhi''', a word which means '''prosperity''' in English, is an annual student-run business conference that takes place at the [[Goa Institute of Management]], India.<ref>{{cite news|last=GSN|title=Samriddhi 2012 Kicks Off in Goa|url=http://www.goasamachar.com/view/samriddhi-2012-kicks-off-in-goa|newspaper=GoaSamachar.com|date=August 18, 2012}}</ref> One of the largest Business School Conferences,<ref name="timesofindia.indiatimes">{{cite news|last=TNN|title=India can be the brainbox of the world, says Alyque Padamsee|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2012-08-18/goa/33261406_1_samriddhi-goa-institute-innovation|newspaper=Times of India|date=August 18, 2012}}</ref> it is a three-day event that features prominent speakers and participants from colleges all over India.<ref>{{cite web|title=B-school conference at Goa Institute of Management|url=http://www.beyondplus2.com/news_details-Aug_13_2012-1511.htm|publisher=beyondplus2.com|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130118123736/http://www.beyondplus2.com/news_details-Aug_13_2012-1511.htm|archivedate=2013-01-18|df=}}</ref>
The main event during Samriddhi is the business conference, where speakers from diverse business backgrounds and interests come together and speak about topics related to the theme of that year's conference. Other events also that take place during the course of the three-day conference include quizzes, case studies, and a photography competition.
== 2012 == The theme for the year 2012 was "The Business of Innovation". Speakers from varying backgrounds came together to speak about their fields of work and explain to students how they brought about innovation. Speakers this year included, amongst others, the Governor of Goa [[Bharat Vir Wanchoo|H.E. Bharat Vir Wanchoo]],<ref>{{cite news|title=India emerging as economic power|url=http://www 21, 2012}}</ref> [[Alyque Padamsee]] (Actor and Ad Guru), Kumar Ankit (Co-founder & Executive Director at Green Leaf Energy Private Limited), Stephen Remedios (Former Head Customer Marketing, HUL),<ref name="timesofindia.indiatimes" /> and Mithileshwar Jha (Professor Marketing at the Indian Institute of Management Bangalore).
The topics ranged from Film making to the Advertising to [[Logistics|Business Logistics]]. In addition to the Business Conference, on the second and third days of the conference, various educational and entertaining events were held for students from Business schools all across India.<ref>[http://www.gim-samriddhi.com/innovation/conference/schedule.html Schedule of Lectures at Samriddhi]</ref>
[[File:Alyque Padamsee, Key Note Speaker.jpg|thumb|Alyque Padamsee addressing students at Samriddhi 2012]]

{{For|other similarly named bodies|Economic and Social Council (disambiguation){{!}}Economic and Social Council}} {{Politics of the Netherlands}}
The '''Sociaal-Economische Raad''' (English: Social and Economic Council; SER) is a major economic advisory council to the [[cabinet of the Netherlands]]. Formally it heads a [[Publiekrechtelijke Bedrijfsorganisatie|system of sector-based regulatory organizations]]. It represents the [[social partners]] [[trade union]]s and [[employers' organization]]s. It forms the core organization of the [[corporatism|corporatist]] and [[social market economy|social market]] [[economy of the Netherlands|economy]] known as the [[polder model]] and the main platform for [[social dialogue]].
==History== The SER was founded in 1950. It was founded after a long debate about the economic order of the Netherlands. The two main governing parties of the time, the Catholic [[Katholieke Volkspartij|KVP]] and the social-democratic [[Dutch Labour Party|PvdA]] had differing opinions on the subject. Both wanted to prevent the repetition of the [[Great Depression|economic crisis of the 1930s]]. The social-democrats preferred to grant the government an important regulatory role in the economy, while the Catholics preferred to rely on the workings of a self-regulating market economy. A compromise was found in the corporatist model, in which both [[Trade unions in the Netherlands|trade unions]] and employers' organizations would form sector-based regulatory organizations. The SER headed this structure and served as important partner for the national government. The SER was very important in the reconstruction of the Netherlands after the [[Second World War]].
In the 1950s and 60s the SER was particularly successful in ensuring economic growth by close cooperation between government, trade unions and employers' organizations. In the 1970s because of rising political [[Polarization (politics)|polarization]] and the [[1973 oil crisis|oil crisis]] the SER was unable to resolve economic problems. In the 1980s the SER returned to the centre of the economic policy making, as it was the platform for dialogue between the government and its [[social partners]]. In the 1990s the role of the SER began to change. The role of the sector-based regulatory organizations began to decline and the SER more and more took the role of an advisory council of government, In 1997 the [[Senate (Netherlands)|Senate]] and [[House of Representatives (Netherlands)|House of Representatives]] were granted the right to submit enquiry commissions to the SER.
==Goals== The SER has three main goals for Dutch social-economic policy: * To promote balanced and [[sustainability|sustainable]] [[economic growth]]; * To promote full employment; * To promote a fair [[income distribution]].
==Organization== [[File:SERDenHaag.JPG|thumb|SER headquarters, [[The Hague]]]] The SER has thirty-three members. It consists of three sections, which each have eleven members in the council. These sections are trade unions, employers' organizations and government appointed members, the so-called Crown members. The trade union-members are appointed from the three major unions: [[Federatie Nederlandse Vakbeweging|FNV]] (8), [[Christelijk Nationaal Vakverbond|CNV]] (2) and the [[Federation of Managerial and Professional Staff Unions|MHP]] (1). The members of the employers' organizations are representatives from the three major employers' organizations: [[VNO-NCW]] (7), [[Midden- en Kleinbedrijf Nederland|MKB]] (3) and the [[Land- en Tuinbouw Organisatie|LTO]] (1). The government-appointed members are normally professors of economics or related fields and they include representatives of the economic planning agency [[CPB (Netherlands)|CPB]] and the central bank [[De Nederlandsche Bank|DNB]]. The board of the SER is formed by four members of each section. The chair of the organization is always a government appointee.
The SER heads and oversees the system of sector-based regulatory organizations. These organizations can like other governments, [[province]]s, [[water board]]s etc. enforce legislation{{examples needed|date=October 2018}} for their members, in this case companies. The SER is financed by levies which companies pay to the [[Chamber of commerce|chambers of commerce]]. It spends €14 million a year.
==Activities== The group has negotiated among other things, agreements in the textile sector, the banking sector and the gold sector. The SER also performs legal and administrative tasks. For example in the field of employee participation, healthy and safe working, employment inspections and pensions.{{huh|date=October 2018}}<!-- Are these binding agreements? What do they cover? Citations? -->
==Chairs== *1950-1958: Frans de Vries *1958-1964: Gerard Stuart *1964-1985: [[Jan de Pous]] *1985-1996: Theo Quené *1996-1998: [[Klaas de Vries (Labour Party)|Klaas de Vries]] *1999-2006: [[Herman Wijffels]] *2006-31 August 2012: [[Alexander Rinnooy Kan]] *1 September 2012-1 July 2014: [[Wiebe Draijer]] *10 September 2014-.. [[Mariëtte Hamer]]
==See also== * [[Economic and Social Committee]] of the [[European Union]].
==External links== * [http://www.ser.nl SER official website]

{{Unreferenced|date=March 2007}} The '''value grid''' model was proposed by Pil and Holweg as a means to show that the way firms compete has shifted away from the linear [[value chain]] way management theory has traditionally thought about value chain management.
The advantages of a value-grid framework, as opposed to value chains, is in allowing companies' managers to strategize and coordinate operations. Common non-linear value chain strategies include influencing demand, modifying information access, exploring [[multitier]] penetration, managing risk, seizing value, integrating value, creating new value propositions, exploiting value chains across tiers, pursuing pinch-point mapping, and defining demand enablers.
==Literature==
Pil, F.K. and Holweg, M. (2006) "Evolving from value chain to value grid." MIT Sloan Management Review, 47(4): 72-80
==See also== *[[Value chain]] *[[Supply chain management]]

{{multiple issues| {{Orphan|date=December 2014}} {{advert|date=December 2014}} {{cleanup|reason=General copy-editing and such, along with the promotional tone.|date=February 2015}} }} {{Infobox company | name = Wemy Industries Limited | logo = | type = Private Company | industry = [[Fast-Moving Consumer Goods|FMCG]] | fate = | predecessor = | successor = | founded = 1978 | founder = | defunct = | hq_location_city = Alapere, Ketu Lagos State | hq_location_country = Nigeria | area_served = | key_people = Ademola Odunaiya (Chairman)
Paul Odunaiya (M.D)
Oba Odunaiya (E.D) | products = | owner = | num_employees = 201-400 | num_employees_year = | parent = | website = {{URL|http://www.wemydrbrowns.com}} }} '''Wemy Industries''' is a Nigerian [[company]] involved in manufacturing and distribution of hygiene products, within the [[Fast-Moving Consumer Goods]] (FMCG) market in [[Nigeria]]. It was founded by Pastor Ademola Odunaiya and his wife, late Dr. (Mrs.) Aderonke Odunaiya in 1978.{{cite web|url=http://www.wemydrbrowns.com/info.html|title=Wemy Industries – Wemy Info|work=wemydrbrowns.com}} It is notable for being the first manufacturer of baby [[diapers]] in [[Nigeria]] and [[West Africa]]. It commenced operation in 1981. == Brand Names == Dr.Brown’s® is a [[brand]] name of sanitary and [[hygiene]] products marketed by Wemy Industries. Dr.Brown’s® sanitary pads and baby diapers were first sold in 1981. Nightingale® [[brand]] of hygiene products is an alternative brand from the stables of Wemy Industries, introduced to the public in 2009. == Category == As of 2014; the company has 37 SKUs. The products ranges are categorized into 3 different care lines according to the company’s handbook. # Baby Carehttp://www.babycaredrbrowns.com # Feminine Carehttp://www.femcaredrbrowns.com # Adult Carehttp://www.adultcaredrbrowns.com == Overview == Traditionally in Nigeria and to some extent West Africa, the use of nappies/diapers/training pants{{cite web|url=http://www.euromonitor.com/nappies-diapers-pants-in-nigeria/report|title=Nappies/Diapers/Pants in Nigeria|work=euromonitor.com}} are low due to the high rate of poverty and illiteracy; it is more so in the [[rural]] areas than the urban areas. Generally, clothes and cotton wools are still used by women who are not able to afford standard [[sanitary]] protection products especially in rural areas.{{cite web|url=http://www.euromonitor.com/sanitary-protection-in-nigeria/report|title=Sanitary Protection in Nigeria|work=euromonitor.com}} One of the common complaints is that the prices of hygiene and sanitary products for women and babies are too high ; such claims about prices are common in the urban areas.In the area of incontinence there is limited awareness about the availability of [[Incontinence pad|incontinence]] products, many incontinence patients can’t even afford specialized care or doctors’ advice, and some are oblivious of the availability of such products.{{cite web|url=http://www.euromonitor.com/incontinence-in-nigeria/report|title=Incontinence in Nigeria|work=euromonitor.com}} This is no longer the norm- thanks to major awareness and education brought in by governmental parastatals and other popular manufacturer including Wemy Industries.Though usage is still relatively low, compared to [[developed countries]]. Wemy Industries Ltd targets middle to [[Low income countries|low income earners]] helping to improve hygiene standards and reduce infant mortality rates. Wemy Industries Ltd has over the years become the only leading domestic player competing with international brands in the local market. == History == *1978 October 25, Wemy Industries Limited was incorporated as a Private Limited Liability (PLL) company to manufacture Dr. Brown’s brand of ladies sanitary pads and children’s disposable nappies. *1981 The company commenced full production of its diapers and sanitary pads at its former site in Isolo, a small residential suburb of [[Lagos state]]. At the time, it was the sole domestic manufacturer of these products in Nigeria. *1983, the company added toilet rolls to its product portfolio. However, this product was discontinued as the company felt that it was not a commercially viable product at the time and decided to commit its efforts and resources to its more profitable product lines. *1984, due to the increasing scope of the company’s operations, Wemy Industries commissioned the building of a new factory in Ota Industrial Estate, [[Ogun State]]. *1990 as a result of the need to further expand, coupled with the desire to be located within the Lagos metropolis, Wemy Industries relocated the factory site to Alapere Ketu, where the company still resides today. *1994 rival companies launched their brands of hygiene products in the Nigeria market, a lot of media buzz was garnered for the health and hygiene industry. Thus, leading Wemy Industries to change strategy and ultimately diversify their product range. *2004 till present, Wemy Industries has consciously increased its product range in order to optimize its revenue streams and fend‐off increasing competition, introducing products such as [[baby wipes]], panty liners, ultra‐thin [[pads]] and [[Child birth|underlay pads]] into the Nigerian market over a few years. *2009 Wemy Industries introduced the Nightingale® brand as an alternative brand in maternity care range of products. *2013 commissioned additional [[factories]] for baby wipes and under-lay towel pads. == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == *{{official|http://www.wemydrbrowns.com}} *[http://www.euromonitors.com euromonitors.com] [[Category:1978 establishments in Nigeria]] [[Category:Manufacturing companies established in 1978]] [[Category:Diaper brands]] [[Category:Manufacturing companies based in Lagos]] [[Category:Nigerian brands]]

A '''work method statement''', sometimes referred to as a '''safe work method statement''' or '''SWMS''' or a '''[[Safe Work Procedure|safe work procedure]]''', is a part of a [[Occupational safety and health|workplace safety]] plan.<ref name="Workcover NSW" /> It is primarily used in construction to describe a document that gives specific instructions on how to safely perform a work related [[Task (project management)|task]], or operate a piece of plant or equipment. In many countries it is law to have work method statements, or similar, in place to advise employees and contractors on how to perform work related tasks safely.<ref name="Workcover NSW">{{cite web | url=http://www.workcover.nsw.gov.au/formspublications/publications/Pages/WC00231_WritingWorkMethodStatementsinPlainEnglis_.aspx | title=Writing work method statements in plain English: Guidelines | accessdate=April 3, 2011 | date=Feb 1998 | publisher=WorkCover Authority NSW Government}}</ref>
The statement is generally used as part of a safety induction and then referred to as required throughout a workplace, they should outline all the hazards that are likely to be encountered when undertaking a task or process and provide detailed guidance on how to carry out the task safely...
==Procedure for use== A work method statement is prepared for each task on a particular worksite, the group of work method statements are then packaged and is typically submitted at the beginning of a project for approval by the client or their representative.
